article.title: AOL

template.arg:
{{start date and age|1983}} (as ''Control Video Corporation'')
1985 (as Quantum Computer Services)
1991(as America Online)
2009 (as AOL Inc.)

[[Tim Armstrong (executive)|Tim Armstrong]]
(Chairman and CEO)
[[Bob Lord]]
(President)
Karen Dykstra
(Executive VP, Chief Financial and Administrative Officer)

[[Independent business|Independent]] (1983-2001, 2009-2015)
AOL Time Warner (2001-2003)
[[Time Warner]] (2003-2009)
[[Verizon Communications]] (2015-present)

article.paragraph: AOL Inc.(previously known asAmerica Online, written asAOLand styled asAol.) is an AmericanMultinational corporationmultinationalmass mediacorporation based inNew York Citythat develops, grows, and invests in brands andweb sites.cite webLundenIngridAOL Reorganizes Into Membership, Brand And Ad Units [Incl Armstrong's Memo]http://techcrunch.com/2012/06/29/aol-reorganizes-into-membership-brand-and-ad-units-incl-armstrongs-memo/TechCrunchJune 29, 2012The company's business spansdigital distributionof content, products, and services, which it offers to consumers, publishers, and advertisers.

AOL originallyInternet service providerprovided dial up serviceto millions of Americans. At the height of its success it merged with media conglomerateTime Warner. As dial up rapidly lost ground to broadband in the mid-2000s, AOL's fortunes significantly retracted and it lost the vast majority of its value, laying off thousands of employees. Time Warner was eventually spun off, and is now worth approximately ten times that of AOL.

On May 12, 2015,Verizon Communicationsannounced plans to buy AOL for $50 per share in a deal valued at $4.4 billion.cite newsImbertFredVerizon to buy AOL for $4.4B; AOL shares soarhttp://www.cnbc.com/id/102670331CNBCMay 12, 2015May 12, 2015The acquisition was completed on June 23, 2015.cite webSawersPaulhttp://venturebeat.com/2015/06/23/verizon-completes-4-4b-acquisition-of-aol/Verizon completes $4.4B acquisition of AOLVentureBeatJune 23, 2015June 23, 2015
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: AOL began in 1983, as a short-lived venture calledControl Video Corporation(orCVC), founded byBill von Meister. Its sole product was an online service calledGameLinefor theAtari 2600video game console, after von Meister's idea of buying music on demand was rejected byWarner Bros.cite bookKleinAlecStealing Time: Steve Case, Jerry Levin, and the Collapse of AOL Time Warner2003Simon & SchusterNew York0-7432-5984-XSubscribers bought amodemfrom the company forUnited States dollarUS$49.95 and paid a one-time US$15 setup fee. GameLine permitted subscribers to temporarily download games and keep track of high scores, at a cost of US$1 per game.cite newsA Brief History of AOLDavid LumbFast Companyhttp://www.fastcompany.com/3046194/fast-feed/a-brief-history-of-aolMay 12, 2015May 12, 2015The telephone disconnected and the downloaded game would remain in GameLine's Master Module and playable until the user turned off the console or downloaded another game.

In January 1983,Steve Casewas hired as a marketing consultant for Control Video on the recommendation of his brother, investment banker Dan Case. In May 1983,Jim Kimseybecame a manufacturing consultant for Control Video, which was near bankruptcy. Kimsey was brought in by his West Point friendFrank Caufield, an investor in the company.In early 1985, von Meister left the company.cite bookMedia Selling: Television, Print, Internet, RadioCharles Warner20111444359274John Wiley & Sons

On May 24, 1985,Quantum Computer Services, an online services company, was founded by Jim Kimsey from the remnants of Control Video, with Kimsey asChief Executive Officer, andMarc SeriffasChief Technology Officer. Out of 100 employees from Control Video, only 10 were retained for the new company,one of whom was Steve Case, who was promoted to vice-president of marketing. In 1987, Case was promoted again to executive vice-president. Kimsey soon began to groom Case to take over the role of CEO, which he did when Kimsey retired in 1991.

Kimsey changed the company's strategy, and in 1985, launched a dedicated online service forCommodore 64andCommodore 128128computers, originally calledQuantum Link("Q-Link" for short).The Quantum Link software was based on software licensed fromPlayNETPlayNet, Inc, (founded in 1983 by Howard Goldberg and Dave Panzl). In May 1988, Quantum andApple ComputerApplelaunchedAppleLinkPersonal Edition forApple II familyApple IITriangulation201Peter FriedmanandApple MacintoshMacintoshcomputers. In August 1988, Quantum launched PC Link, a service for IBM-compatiblepersonal computerPCsdeveloped in a joint venture with theTandy Corporation. After the company parted ways with Apple in October 1989, Quantum changed the service's name to America Online.cite webhttp://www.thocp.net/timeline/1989.htmHistory of Computing Industrial Era (1985–1990)The History of Computing ProjectSeptember 24, 2005March 20, 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20051103111647/http://www.thocp.net/timeline/1989.htm3 November 2005nocite webhttp://apple2history.org/history/ah22.htmlApple II history chapter 22December 31, 2002September 24, 2005https://web.archive.org/web/20050828233812/http://apple2history.org/history/ah22.html28 August 2005noCase was promoted to and sold AOL as the online service for people unfamiliar with computers, in contrast toCompuServe, which was well established in the technical community.

From the beginning, AOL includedonline gamesin its mix of products; many classic and casual games were included in the original PlayNet software system. In the early years of AOL the company introduced many innovative online interactive titles and games, including:

list.listitem: Graphical chat environmentsHabitat (video game)Habitat(19861988) andClub Caribe(1988) fromLucasArts.
The first online interactive fiction seriesQuantumLink SerialbyTracy Reed (writer)Tracy Reed(1988).
Quantum Space, the first fully automatedPlay-by-mail gamePlay by emailgame (19891991).

article.heading: 1990s: a new Internet age
article.paragraph: In February 1991, AOL forDOSwas launched using aGeoWorksinterface followed a year later by AOL for Windows.This coincided with growth in pay-based online services, likeProdigy (ISP)Prodigy,CompuServe, andGEnie. 1991 also saw the introduction of an originalDungeons & Dragonstitle calledNeverwinter Nights (AOL game)Neverwinter NightsfromStormfront Studios; which was one of the first Multiplayer Online Role Playing Games to depict the adventure with graphics instead of text.The History of NWM

During the early 1990s, the average subscription lasted for about 25 months and accounted for $350 in total revenue.cite webhttp://www.quora.com/AOL-History/How-much-did-it-cost-AOL-to-distribute-all-those-CDs-back-in-the-1990sAOL History: How much did it cost AOL to distribute all those CDs back in the 1990's?Quora2010-12-24July 13, 2012yeshttps://web.archive.org/20121027155641/http://www.quora.com/AOL-History/How-much-did-it-cost-AOL-to-distribute-all-those-CDs-back-in-the-1990sOctober 27, 2012AOL discontinued Q-Link and PC Link in late 1994. In September 1993, AOL addedUSENETaccess to its features.Catb.org. Catb.org. Retrieved on July 8, 2011.This is commonly referred to as the "Eternal September". AOL quickly surpassedGEnie, and by the mid-1990s, it passedProdigy (ISP)Prodigy(which for several years allowed AOL advertising) andCompuServe.By 1993, AOL was able to provideInternetpublic Internetaccess for itsMicrosoft WindowsWindowsclient users.cite newshttp://time.com/3857628/aol-1985-history/TimeMay 22, 2015A Brief Guide to the Tumultuous 30-Year History of AOLLily Rothman

Over the next several years, AOL launched services with theNational Education Association, theAmerican Federation of Teachers,National Geographic (magazine)National Geographic, theSmithsonian Institution, theLibrary of Congress, Pearson, Scholastic, ASCD, NSBA, NCTE, Discovery Networks, Turner Education Services (CNN Newsroom), National Public Radio, The Princeton Review, Stanley Kaplan, Barron's, Highlights for Kids, the US Department of Education, and many other education providers. AOL offered the first real-time homework help service (the Teacher Pager1990; prior to this, AOL provided homework help bulletin boards), the first service by children, for children (Kids Only Online, 1991), the first online service for parents (the Parents Information Network, 1991), the first online courses (1988), the first omnibus service for teachers (the Teachers' Information Network, 1990), the first online exhibit (Library of Congress, 1991), the first parental controls, and many other online education firsts.cite bookNetstudyMichael WolffDell Publishing1997

AOL charged its users an hourly fee untilDecember 1996, when the company changed to a flat monthly rate of $19.95.During this time, AOL connections would be flooded with users trying to get on, and many canceled their accounts due to constantbusy signals. A commercial featuring Steve Case telling people AOL was working day and night to fix the problem was made. Within three years, AOL's userbase grew to 10 million people. In 1995 AOL was headquartered at 8619 Westwood Center Drive in theTysons Corner, VirginiaTysons Corner CDPinunincorporated areaunincorporatedFairfax County, VirginiaFairfax County, Virginia,cite webhttp://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-832840.html//wayback.archive.org/web/20091119074042/http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-832840.html19 November 2009Encyclopedia.comencyclopedia.com''[[The Washington Post]]''April 17, 2005May 7, 2009"Tysons Corner CDP, Virginia."United States Census Bureau. Retrieved on May 7, 2009.waybackhttp://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id20140714060513near theVienna, VirginiaTown of Vienna.Sugawara, Sandra. "America Online to Reduce Rates; Firm Faces Subscriber Boycott, Pressure From Competitors."The Washington Post. October 13, 1994. Financial B09. Retrieved on May 7, 2009.

AOL was quickly running out of room in October 1996 for its network at the Fairfax County campus. In 1996, AOL moved to 22000 AOL Way inDulles, VirginiaDulles, unincorporatedLoudoun County, Virginia.cite webhttp://corp.aol.com/about-aol/company-overview//web.archive.org/web/20080208121604/http://corp.aol.com/about-aol/company-overview8 February 2008Company Overviewcorp.aol.com''AOL''February 8, 2008The move to Dulles took place in mid-1996 and provided room for future growth. In a five-year landmark agreement with the most popular operating system, AOL was bundled with Windows software.cite bookBreaking Windows: How Bill Gates Fumbled the Future of MicrosoftSimon and SchusterDavid Bank20019780743203159105

On March 31, 1997, the short-livedeWorldwas purchased by AOL. In 1997, about half of all US homes with internet access had it through AOL."The Fall of Facebook". (December 2014).The Atlantic, pp. 35.During this time, AOL's content channels, underJason Seiken, including News, Sports, and Entertainment, experienced their greatest growth as AOL become the dominant online service internationally with more than 34 million subscribers. In November 1998, AOL announced it would acquireNetscape.The deal closed on March 17, 1999.
article.heading: 2000s: Transition re-branding and decline
article.paragraph: File:Aol subscribers Q201-Q407.pngthumbrightDecline in U.S. subscribers 2Q 2001 2Q 2009.In January 2000, AOL andTime Warnerannounced plans to merge, forming AOL Time Warner, Inc. The terms of the deal called for AOL shareholders to own 55% of the new, combined company. The deal closed on January 11, 2001. The new company was led by executives from AOL, SBI, and Time Warner.Gerald Levin, who had served as CEO of Time Warner, was CEO of the new company. Steve Case served as Chairman, J. Michael Kelly (from AOL) was the Chief Financial Officer,Robert W. Pittman(from AOL) andDick Parsons(from Time Warner) served as Co-Chief Operating Officers.Cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/11/business/media/11merger.html?_rHow the AOL-Time Warner Merger Went So WrongTim Arango[[The New York Times]]January 10, 2010

In 2002,Jonathan Miller (businessman)Jonathan Millerbecame CEO of AOL.cite newsHenry, Shannon7 August 2002At AOL, New Boss Largely Unknown; 'Who's Jon Miller?' Employees Ask At Dulles Offices[[Wash. Post]]http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-366982.html[[HighBeam Research]]Note: only the beginning of the news article was available, the remainder behind a paywall.
In 2003 AOL Time Warner dropped the "AOL" from its name.

In 2004, along with the launch of AOL 9.0 Optimized, AOL also made available the option of personalized greetings which would enable the user to hear his or her name while accessing basic functions and mail alerts, or while logging in or out. In 2005, AOL broadcast theLive 8concert live over the Internet, and thousands of users downloaded clips of the concert over the following months.cite journalLive 8BillboardJul 29, 200622In late 2005, AOL released AOL Safety & Security Center, a bundle of McAfee anti-virus,Computer AssociatesCAanti-spyware, and proprietary firewall and phishing protection software.cite journalProtect your PCKiplinger's Personal FinanceJuly 2007Jeff BertolucciNews reports in late 2005 identified companies such asYahoo!,Microsoft, andGoogleas candidates for turning AOL into a joint venture.cite newshttp://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/nov2005/tc20051111_725373.htmHas AOL Met Its Match?CatherineYangBusinessWeekNovember 11, 2005August 1, 2006Those plans were abandoned when it was revealed on December 20, 2005 that Google would purchase a 5% share of AOL for $1 billion.

On April 3, 2006, AOL announced it was retiring the full name America Online; the official name of the service became AOL, and the full name of the Time Warner subdivision became AOLLimited liability companyLLC.cite newshttp://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,1179447,00.htmlAmerica Online Changes Its Name to AOLApril 3, 2006July 24, 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060715034643/http://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,1179447,00.html15 July 2006no

On June 8, 2006,AOL Launches Free Software To Improve PC Security For All Internet Users. Timewarner.com. Retrieved on July 8, 2011.AOL offered a new program called AOL Active Security Monitor, a diagnostic tool which checked the local PC's security status, and recommended additional security software from AOL orDownload.com. The program rated the computer on a variety of different areas of security and general computer health. Two months later,cite newshttp://press.aol.com/article_display.cfm?article_id//wayback.archive.org/web/20070623105247/http://press.aol.com/article_display.cfm?article_id23 June 2007AOL News and Broadcast CenterPress.aol.comNovember 11, 2010July 8, 2011AOL releasedAOL Active Virus Shield. This software was developed byKaspersky Lab. Active Virus Shield software was free and did not require an AOL account, only an internet email address. TheInternet service providerISPside of AOL UK was bought byThe Carphone Warehousein October 2006 to take advantage of their 100,000Local-loop unbundlingLLUcustomers, making The Carphone Warehouse the biggest LLU provider in the UK.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6039740.stmBBC NewsCarphone Warehouse buying AOL UKOctober 11, 2006April 25, 2010

On August 2006, AOL announced they would give away email accounts and software previously available only to its paying customers provided the customer accessed AOL or AOL.com through a non-AOL-owned access method (otherwise known as "third party transit", "bring your own access", or "BYOA"). The move was designed to reduce costs associated with the "Walled Garden" business model by reducing usage of AOL-owned access points and shifting members with high-speed internet access from client-based usage to the more lucrative advertising provider, AOL.com.AOL scraps fees in bid to keep users. USA Today. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.The change from paid to free was also designed to slow the rate of members canceling their accounts and defecting toMicrosoftHotmail,Yahoo!, or other free email providers. The other free services included:cite newshttp://www.themoneytimes.com/articles/20061004/aol_uses_refurbished_software_to_woo_customers-id-101785.htmlAOL Uses Refurbished Software to Woo CustomersThe Money TimesOctober 4, 2006November 11, 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20061110231338/http://www.themoneytimes.com/articles/20061004/aol_uses_refurbished_software_to_woo_customers-id-101785.html10 November 2006no

list.listitem: AIM (AOL Instant Messenger)
AOL VideoVideo.aol.com. Video.aol.com (November 11, 2010). Retrieved on July 8, 2011.featured professional content and allowed users to upload videos as well.

AOL Local, comprising its CityGuide,cite webhttp://cityguide.aol.com/Cityguide.aol.comCityguide.aol.com2014-04-25Yellow PagesYellowpages.aol.com. Yellowpages.aol.com. Retrieved on July 8, 2011.and Local Searchcite webhttp://local.aol.com/Local.aol.comLocal.aol.comJuly 8, 2011services to help users find local information like restaurants, local events, and directory listings.
AOL News
AOL My eAddress, a customdomain namefor email addresses. These email accounts could be accessed in a manner similar to other AOL and AIM email accounts.

Xdrive, which was a service offered by AOL, allowed users to back up their files over the Internet.cite newsPogueDavidFewer excuses for not doing a PC backupThe New York TimesJanuary 6, 2007http://news.cnet.com/Fewer+excuses+for+not+doing+a+PC+backup/2100-1046_3-6147459.html?tagJanuary 6, 2007Quote: "Online backups, where files are shuttled off to the Internet for safekeeping, are suddenly becoming effortless, capacious and even free."It was acquired by AOL on August 3, 2005 and closed on January 12, 2009.cite newsXdrive storage site to close[[Webuser]] IPC Media LimitedJanuary 5, 2009January 19, 2009http://www.webuser.co.uk/news/news.php?idDead linkJanuary 2015It offered a free 5GigabyteGBaccount (freeonline file storage) to anyone with an AOL screenname.cite newsPogueDavid Fewer excuses for not doing a PC backupThe New York TimesJanuary 6, 2007http://news.cnet.com/Fewer+excuses+for+not+doing+a+PC+backup/2100-1046_3-6147459.html?tag2007-01-06Quote: "Online backups, where files are shuttled off to the Internet for safekeeping, are suddenly becoming effortless, capacious and even free."Xdrive also provided remote backup services and 50GB of storage for a $9.95 per month fee.

article.paragraph: In late 2006, Randy Falco succeeded Jonathan Miller as CEO.cite webhttp://techwhack.co/randy-falco-aol-ceo/Randy Falco is the new CEO of AOLTechWhackIn December 2006, AOL closed their last remaining call center in the United States, "taking the America out of America Online" according to industry pundits. Service centers based in India and the Philippines continue to this day to provide customer support and technical assistance to subscribers.cite newsAmerica Online to close city call centerJimStaffordDecember 2, 2006[[The Oklahoman]]http://newsok.com/america-online-to-close-city-call-center/article/2979966

According to AOL CEO Randy Falco, as of December 2007, the conversion rate of accounts from paid access to free access was over 80%.cite webhttp://www.alleyinsider.com/2007/12/aol-twx-randy-falcos-yearend-love-note-to-aolers.htmlAOL (TWX): Randy Falco's Year-End Love Note to AOLersDecember 18, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20071218120637/http://www.alleyinsider.com/2007/12/aol-twx-randy-falcos-yearend-love-note-to-aolers.html18 December 2007noLater in August 2006, AOL informed its American customers it would be increasing the price of itsdial-up accessto US$25.90. The increase was part of an effort to migrate the service's remaining dial-up users to broadband, as the increased price was the same price they had been charging for monthlyDigital subscriber lineDSLaccess.cite webhttp://news.cnet.com/AOL+hanging+up+on+dial-up+customers/2100-1025_3-6043910.html?tagAOL hanging up on dial-up customers?MillsElinorCNETAugust 3, 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20060814003308/http://news.cnet.com/AOL+hanging+up+on+dial-up+customers/2100-1025_3-6043910.html?tag14 August 2006noHowever, AOL has since started offering their services for $9.95 a month for unlimited dial-up access.cite webhttp://free.aol.com/thenewaol/plan_choice.adpAOL price plansOctober 29, 2006https://web.archive.org/web/20061101213626/http://free.aol.com/thenewaol/plan_choice.adp1 November 2006no

On September 17, 2007, AOL announced it was moving one of its corporate headquarters fromDulles, Virginia, to New York Citycite newshttp://online.wsj.com/article/SB119003377082529719.html?modAOL Moves Headquarters To New York CitySeptember 17, 2007September 17, 2007The Wall Street JournalEmilySteeland combining its various advertising units into a new subsidiary called Platform A. This action followed several advertising acquisitions, most notablyAdvertising.com, and highlighted the company's new focus on advertising-driven business models. AOL management stressed "significant operations" will remain in Dulles, which included the company's access services and modem banks.

In October 2007, AOL announced it would move one of its other headquarters fromLoudoun County, Virginia, to New York City; it would continue to operate its Virginia offices.cite newsGoldfarb, Zachary and Sam Diazhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/17/AR2007091700415.htmlThe Washington PostAOL Moving Executives, Headquarters to New YorkSeptember 18, 2007May 7, 2009As part of the impending move to New York and the restructuring of responsibilities at the Dulles headquarters complex after the Reston move, AOL CEORandy Falcoannounced on October 15, 2007 plans to lay off 2000 employees worldwide by the end of 2007, beginning "immediately".cite newshttp://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/10/15/tuesday-is-layoff-day-at-aol/Tuesday is Layoff Day at AOLOctober 15, 2007October 17, 2007The New York TimesSaulHansellhttps://web.archive.org/web/20071017022954/http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/10/15/tuesday-is-layoff-day-at-aol/17 October 2007noThe end result was a near 40% layoff across the board at AOL. Most compensation packages associated with the October 2007 layoffs included a minimum of 120 days of severance pay, 60 of which were given in lieu of the 60-day advance notice requirement by provisions of the 1988 FederalWorker Adjustment and Retraining Notification ActWARN Act.

By November 2007, AOL's customer base had been reduced to 10.1 million subscribers,cite newshttp://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?commandAOL revenue, subscribers plummetLindaRosencranceComputerWorldNovember 8, 2007November 12, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20071117090816/http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command17 November 2007nojust narrowly ahead ofComcastandAT&T Yahoo!.

On January 3, 2008, AOL announced the closing of one of its three Northern Virginia data centers,Reston, VirginiaReston Technology Center, and sold it toCRG West.cite newshttp://www.crgwest.com/PDFs/12100_Sunrise_Press_Release.pdfPDFCRG West accounces the acquisition of Data Center in Reston, VirginiaJanuary 3, 2008November 16, 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20081217094718/http://www.crgwest.com/PDFs/12100_Sunrise_Press_Release.pdf17 December 2008noOn February 6, Time Warner CEOJeffrey BewkesJeff Bewkesannounced Time Warner would split AOL's internet access and advertising businesses in two, with the possibility of later selling the internet access division.cite newshttp://biz.yahoo.com/ap/080206/earns_time_warner.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080207234015/http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/080206/earns_time_warner.html2008-02-07Time Warner Will Split AOL: Financial News – Yahoo! Financebiz.yahoo.com

On March 13, AOL purchased the social networking siteBebofor $850m (417m).BBC NEWS | BusinessAOL acquires Bebo social networkOn July 25, AOL announced it was shedding Xdrive, AOL Pictures, and BlueString to save on costs and focus on its core advertising business.Washingtonpost.comDead linkJanuary 2015, AOL shutting 3 services to cut costs, focus on adsAOL Pictures was terminated on December 31, 2008. On October 31, 2008,AOL Hometown(a web hosting service for the websites of AOL customers) and the AOL Journal blog hosting service were eliminated.cite webhttp://www.peopleconnectionblog.com/2008/09/30/were-closing-our-doors///wayback.archive.org/web/20081028165439/http://www.peopleconnectionblog.com/2008/09/30/were-closing-our-doors/28 October 2008We're Closing Our DoorsPeopleConnectionBlog.comAOL
article.heading: 20092015: AOL as a digital media company
article.paragraph: On March 12, 2009,Tim Armstrong (executive)Tim Armstrong, formerly withGoogle, was named Chairman and CEO of AOL.Tim Armstrong Named Chairman and CEO of AOL. AOL Press Release. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.Shortly thereafter, on May 28,Time Warnerannounced it would spin off AOL as an independent company onceGoogle's shares ceased at the end of the fiscal year.Time Warner walking out on AOL marriage. MSNBC (May 28, 2009). Retrieved on July 8, 2011.On November 23, AOL unveiled a sneak preview of a new brand identity which has the wordmarkAolsuperimposed onto canvases created by commissioned artists. The new identity, designed byWolff Olins,cite webPublic Classhttp://www.wolffolins.com/work/aolAOLWolff OlinsJanuary 30, 2012was enacted onto all of AOL's services on December 10, the date AOL traded independently for the first time since the Time Warner merger on theNew York Stock Exchangeunder the symbol AOL.AOL Celebrates Day One as an Independent Company. AOL Press Release. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.

On April 6, 2010, AOL announced plans to shut down or sell Bebo;cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/social-media/7562278/AOL-prepares-to-shut-down-Bebo.htmlAOL prepares to shut down Bebotelegraph.co.ukApril 6, 2010LondonEmmaBarnettApril 7, 2010on June 16, the property was sold toCriterion Capital Partnersfor an undisclosed amount, believed to be around $10 million.AOL sells Bebo for scrap and a $275 million tax break. CNN Money. Retrieved on April 12, 2011.In December, AIM eliminated access to AOL chat rooms noting a marked decline of patronage in recent months.Why is AIM Chat Closed?. AOL Help. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.

Under Armstrongs leadership, AOL began taking steps in a new business direction, marked by a series of acquisitions. On June 11, 2009, AOL had already announced the acquisition of Patch Media, a network of community-specific news and information sites which focuses on individual towns and communities.cite webSwisherKaraBack to the Future: AOL Goes Local With Two Acquisitions (Including CEO's Company)http://allthingsd.com/20090611/back-to-the-future-aol-adds-local-with-two-acquisitions-including-ceos-start-up/AllThingsDJune 11, 2009On September 28, 2010, at the San FranciscoTechCrunchDisrupt Conference, AOL signed an agreement to acquireTechCrunchto further its overall strategy of providing premier online content.cite newshttp://techcrunch.com/2010/09/28/tim-armstrong-we-got-techcrunch/We Got TechCrunch!September 28, 2010September 29, 2010TechCrunchTimArmstronghttps://web.archive.org/web/20101001004758/http://techcrunch.com/2010/09/28/tim-armstrong-we-got-techcrunch/1 October 2010nocite newshttp://techcrunch.com/2010/09/28/why-we-sold-techcrunch-to-aol-and-where-we-go-from-here/Why We Sold TechCrunch to AOL and Where We Go From HereSeptember 28, 2010September 29, 2010TechCrunchMichaelArringtonhttps://web.archive.org/web/20100929180016/http://techcrunch.com/2010/09/28/why-we-sold-techcrunch-to-aol-and-where-we-go-from-here/29 September 2010noOn December 12, 2010, AOL acquiredabout.me, a personal profile and identity platform, four days after that latter's public launch.AOL Acquires Personal Profile Startup About.Me. TechCrunch. Retrieved April 9, 2012.

On January 31, 2011, AOL announced the acquisition of European video distribution network, goviral.ONLINE VIDEO DISTRIBUTION NETWORK GOVIRAL ACQUIRED BY AOL EUROPE. AOL Press Release. Retrieved April 9, 2012.On February 7, AOL boughtThe Huffington Postfor $315 million.AOL buys Huffington Post: the beginning of the end?. Guardian. Retrieved on July 8, 2011.Shortly after the acquisition was announced, Huffingtonpost.com co-founderArianna Huffingtonreplaced AOL Content Chief David Eun, assuming the role of President and Editor-in-Chief of the AOL Huffington Post Media Group.Wired.com. Wired.com. Retrieved on July 8, 2011.On March 10, AOL announced it would cut around 900 workers in the wake of the Huffington Post deal.AOL cuts 900 jobs after HuffPo buy. CNN Money. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.

On September 14, 2011, AOL formed a strategic ad selling partnership with two of its largest competitors, Yahoo and Microsoft. According to the new partnership, the three companies would begin selling inventory on each others sites. The strategy was designed to help them compete with Google and ad networks.cite webhttp://allthingsd.com/20110914/all-for-one-yahoo-aol-microsoft-band-together-for-ad-plan/allthingsd.comallthingsd.comSeptember 14, 2011January 30, 2012

On March 15, 2012, AOL announced the acquisition of Hipster, a mobile photo sharing app for an undisclosed amount.AOL acquires mobile photo-sharing app Hipster. VentureBeat. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.On April 9, 2012, AOL announced a deal to sell 800 patents toMicrosoftfor $1.056 billion. The deal includes a "perpetual" license for AOL to use these patents.AOL and Microsoft Announce $1.056 Billion Deal. AOL Press Release. Retrieved on April 9, 2012.

In April, AOL took several steps to expand its ability to generate revenue through online video advertising. The company announced it would offergross rating point(GRP) guarantee for online video, mirroring the TV ratings system and guaranteeing audience delivery for online video advertising campaigns bought across its properties.cite webThielmanSamNielsen, AOL Chase Ads With TV-Like Ratings Web giant issues bold guarantees regarding its online GRP'shttp://www.adweek.com/news/technology/nielsen-aol-chase-ads-tv-ratings-139593AdWeekApril 16, 2012This announcement came just days before the Digital Content NewFront (DCNF), a two-week event held by AOL, Google, Hulu, Microsoft, Vevo and Yahoo to showcase the participating sites digital video offerings. TheDigital Content NewFrontwere conducted in advance of the traditional television upfronts in hopes of diverting more advertising money into the digital space.cite newsVEGA and STUART ELLIOTTTANZINASmall Screens, Big Dollarshttp://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/27/business/media/newfronts-make-bids-for-big-marketing-dollars.html?_rThe New York TimesApril 26, 2012April 26, 2012On April 24, the company launched the AOL On network, a single web site for its video output.cite newsCoyleJakeApril 24, 2012AOL launches online video network, AOL Onhttp://news.yahoo.com/aol-launches-online-video-network-aol-222116148.htmlAssociated PressMay 1, 2012

In February 2013, AOL reported its fourth quarter revenue of $599.5 million, its first growth in quarterly revenue in 8 years.cite newsHageyKeachhttp://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323452204578291641794924434.htmlAOL Quarterly Revenue Rises for First Time in Years - WSJ.comOnline.wsj.com2013-02-082013-02-14

In August 2013, Armstrong announced Patch Media would scale back or sell hundreds of its local news sites.cite webhttp://allthingsd.com/20130809/400-patch-sites-on-the-block-aol-says/400 Patch Sites on the Block, AOL SaysPeterKafkaAllThingsDAugust 9, 2013August 22, 2013Not long afterwards, layoffs began, with up to 500 out of 1,100 positions initially impacted.cite newshttp://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887324823804579016792559044128.htmlAOL Begins Layoffs At PatchKeachHageyThe Wall Street JournalAugust 16, 2013August 22, 2013On January 15, 2014, Patch Media was spun off, with majority ownership being held by Hale Global.cite newsAOL Finds a Partner to Run Its Troubled Patch Divisionhttp://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/16/business/media/aol-finds-a-partner-to-run-its-troubled-patch-division.htmlKaufmanLeslieJanuary 15, 2014New York TimesBy the end of 2014, AOL controlled 0.74% of the global advertising market, well behind industry leader Google's 31.4%.
article.heading: 2015-present: Purchase by Verizon Communications
article.paragraph: On May 12, 2015,Verizonannounced plans to buy AOL for $50 per share in a deal valued at $4.4 billion. The transaction was completed on June 23. Armstrong, who continued to lead the firm following regulatory approval, called the deal the logical next step for AOL. "If you look forward five years, you're going to be in a space where there are going to be massive, global-scale networks, and there's no better partner for us to go forward with than Verizon." he said. "It's really not about selling the company today. It's about setting up for the next five to 10 years."

Analyst David Bank said he thought the deal made sense for Verizon.The deal will broaden Verizon's advertising sales platforms and increase its video production ability through websites such asThe Huffington Post,TechCrunch, andEngadget.Cite newsVerizon buys AOL for $4.4bnhttp://www.bbc.com/news/business-32702558BBCMay 12, 2015May 12, 2015However, Craig Moffett said it was unlikely the deal would make a big difference to Verizon's bottom line.AOL had about two million dial-up subscribers at the time of the buyout.The announcement caused AOL's stock price to rise 17%, while Verizon's stock price dropped slightly.

On June 29, 2015, AOL announced a deal withMicrosoftto take over the majority of its digital advertising business. Under the pact, as many as 1200 Microsoft employees involved with the business will be transferred to AOL, and the company will take over the sale of display, video, and mobile ads on various Microsoft platforms in nine countries, including Brazil, Canada, the United States, and the United Kingdom. Additionally,Google Searchwill be replaced on AOL properties withBingwhich will display advertisingBing Adssold by Microsoft. Both advertising deals are subject toaffiliate marketingrevenue sharing.cite newsAOL in Deal With Microsoft to Take Over Display Ad Businesshttp://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/30/business/aol-in-deal-with-microsoft-to-take-over-display-ad-business.html?_r30 June 2015The New York TimesDinoGrandoniJune 29, 2015cite newsAOL Takes Over Majority of Microsoft’s Ad Business, Swaps Google Search For Binghttp://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2015/06/29/aol-takes-over-majority-of-microsofts-ad-business-swaps-google-search-for-bing/30 June 2015Wall Street JournalMikeShieldsShiraOvideJune 29, 2015
article.heading: Products and services
article.paragraph: AOL's products and services are in the following areas: Content, Advertising, Local, Membership and AOL Ventures.
article.heading: Content
article.paragraph: AOL's Huffington Post Media Group, led byArianna Huffington, is a source of news, opinion, entertainment, community and digital information. The separate AOL Brand Group, led by Luke Beatty, is a diverse network of sites includingMoviefone,Engadget,Autoblog (website)Autoblog,TechCrunch,Cambioand Stylelist, which combine reposting, technology, engagement, and video to reach a global audience on every platform. The group has over 20,000 bloggers, including politicians, celebrities, academics and policy experts, who contribute on a wide range of topics making news.cite webAOL Products and Services: Contenthttp://corp.aol.com/products-services/content2012-07-24The group's video is collected on its AOL On site, which offers channels in News, Entertainment, Style, Tech, Business, Food, Home, Travel, Health, Autos, Parenting, Relationships, Video Games and Pets.cite webAOL Onhttp://on.aol.com/2012-07-24
article.heading: Advertising
article.paragraph: AOL Advertising offers advertisers, agencies and publishers access to AOL's online advertising tools, and the ability to advertise on the original brands available through the AOL Huffington Post Media Group.

list.listitem: AOL Advertising.com Group The AOL Advertising.com Group comprises eight businesses: Advertising.com, ADTECH, AOL On Network, 5min Media, Be On, Pictela, StudioNow, and Sponsored Listings.

Advertising.com AOL's ad network,Advertising.com, helps advertisers reach highly targeted audiences at scale, and helps publishers increase revenue. Advertising.com utilizes AdLearn, an advanced optimization and bid management system. AdLearn processes up to 10 billion transactions per day.

ADTECHADTECH's integrated ad serving solutions enable web publishers, ad networks, agencies and advertisers to manage, serve and report on their online advertising campaigns including display, video and mobile formats.

AOL On Network The AOL On Network comprises 14 curated video channels. It features original series by AOL Studios and other production houses, and a library of content from AOL partners. The site is refreshed with content surrounding breaking stories and trending topics. AOL On also features the custom playlists of celebrity curators.

5min Media 5min Media offers publishers access to a curated video library, white-label player and proprietary technology which allows them to integrate 5min Medias videos across their sites to reach and be seen by targeted audiences.
Be On Be On distributes branded video content on a pay-for-performance basis.

Pictela Pictela is an award-winning,cite webhttp://www.360i.com/reports/iab-rising-stars/The IAB's Rising Star Ad Unitswww.360i.com2008-07-072011-03-01high-definition global content marketing platform for serving and distributing brand content across online advertising and social media. The Pictela platform powers the backend of AOL Premium Formats.
StudioNow StudioNow works with businesses to create, produce and distribute affordable custom video that's hyperlocal, high-quality and scaled to their needs.

Sponsored Listings The Advertising.com Sponsored Listings network includes AOL Media properties and many of the web's top sites. The network is pay-per-click and enables advertisers to target ads by content and by audience.cite webAOL Products & Services – Advertisinghttp://corp.aol.com/products-services/advertising2012-07-24

article.heading: Local
article.paragraph: AOL provides local content, platforms and services covering geographic levels ranging from neighborhoods to major metropolitan areas. This local content includes professional editorial content, user-generated content and business listings. AOL's local brands includeMapQuest, the second-largest online mapping company, operating at 44-percent market share; and a minority holding inPatch MediaPatch, a platform of hyperlocal news and information sites managed by professional local journalists and photographers.
article.heading: AOL membership
article.paragraph: AOL offers a range of integrated products and properties including communication tools, mobile services and subscription packages which drive traffic across the AOL network.

list.listitem: Dial upInternet access - According to AOL quarterly earnings report May 8, 2015, 2.1 million people use AOL's dial-up service.cite webMatyszczykChrisMore than 2 million people still pay for AOL dial-uphttp://www.cnet.com/news/more-than-2-million-people-still-pay-for-aol-dialup/CNET8 May 2015

Mobile AOL Mobile includes applications and mobile web experiences for existing AOL properties like Moviefone, TechCrunch, AIM, MapQuest, and products such as Engadget Distro, Editions by AOL, Play by AOL Music, and Huffington Magazine.
AOL MailAOL Mail is AOL's proprietary email client. It is fully integrated with AIM and links to news headlines on AOL content sites.
AOL Instant Messenger(AIM) - is AOL's proprietary instant-messaging tool. It also comprises a video-chat service, AV by AIM.

Lifestore.com Lifestore.com provides products and services including PC utilities, tech support, online learning, and diet and fitness programs.cite webAOL Products & Services – AOL Membershiphttp://corp.aol.com/products-services/aol-membership2012-07-24

article.heading: AOL Desktop

template.arg: [[Microsoft Windows XP]] or later, [[Mac OS X 10.4]].8 or later

article.paragraph: AOL Desktopis an internet suite produced by AOL that integrates aweb browser, aMedia player (application software)media playerand aninstant messengerclient.Based onAOL OpenRide,cite webhttp://beta.aol.com/projects/chat/chat_logs/20070808_Helix_FormalChat.htmlAugust 8th Helix Beta Chataol.comit is an upgrade from such.cite webhttp://betanews.com/2007/07/26/aol-heads-in-new-direction-with-helix/AOL Heads in New Direction with 'Helix'BetaNewsThe Mac OS X version is based onWebKit.

AOL Desktop is different from previous AOL browsers, which are still available. Its features are focused on browsing instead ofemail. For instance, one does not have to sign into AOL in order to use it as a regular browser. In addition, non-AOL email accounts can be accessed through it. There are three main buttons: "MAIL", "IM", and "WEB". The first two require users to sign in but "WEB" can be instantly used.
article.heading: Ventures
article.paragraph: AOL Ventures is the venture capital arm of AOL and invests in early-stage technology-centric consumer Internet companies.cite webAOL Products & Services – AOL Ventureshttp://corp.aol.com/products-services/aol-ventures2012-07-24
article.heading: Corporate social responsibility
article.paragraph: Since spinning off from Time Warner in 2010, AOL has made corporate social responsibility an important part of its mission. In its company values, AOL states, "We are in the business of helping people, period."cite webAOL Corporate Site – Our Valueshttp://corp.aol.com/our-values2012-07-25For the companys corporate social responsibility efforts, AOL's CEO Tim Armstrong was included in a July 9, 2012 Adweek article, "The Givers," highlighting individuals who have committed their and their companies' time, money and resources to a diverse range of causes.cite webThe Givershttp://www.adweek.com/news-gallery/advertising-branding/givers-141741AdweekJuly 9, 2012

Each year on the companys birthday, AOL employees around the world are invited to participate in Monster Help Day, a global community service day dedicated to strengthening the communities in which AOL employees live and work.cite webAOL Impact – Monster Help Dayhttp://impact.aol.com/monster-help-day/AOL2012-07-25Other corporate social responsibility initiatives include producing cause-related content for AOL properties; donating PSA campaigns throughout the AOL network; empowering consumers through cause-related contests and initiatives; implementing a permanent cause module on AOL's homepage, dedicated to promoting a different nonprofit daily; and advocating for internet safety through its blog SafetyClicks.com.cite webAOL Corporate Site – Corporate Citizenshiphttp://corp.aol.com/our-values/corporate-citizenshipAOL2012-07-25
article.heading: Criticism
article.paragraph: mainCriticism of AOLIn its earlier incarnation as aClosed platformwalled gardencommunity and service provider, AOL received criticism for its community policies, terms of service, and customer service. Prior to 2006, AOL was known for its direct mailing of CD-ROMs and 3" floppy disks containing its software. The disks were distributed in large numbers; at one point, half of the CDs manufactured worldwide had AOL logos on them.cite webhttp://techcrunch.com/2010/12/27/aol-discs-90s/Comment How Much Did It Cost AOL To Send Us Those CDs In The 90s? "A Lot!," Says Steve CaseTech CrunchDecember 27, 20102013-06-11Siegler, MThe marketing tactic was criticized for its environmental cost, and AOL CDs were recognized as PCWorlds most annoying tech product.cite newsDorninRustyCD overload? Send them back to AOLhttp://articles.cnn.com/2002-10-17/tech/aol.discs_1_million-discs-aol-discs-aol-spokesman?_shttps://web.archive.org/web/20130224092739/http://articles.cnn.com/2002-10-17/tech/aol.discs_1_million-discs-aol-discs-aol-spokesman?_s2013-02-24CNN TechOctober 17, 2002October 17, 2002cite webYour Top 10 Most Annoying Tech Productshttp://www.pcworld.com/article/130647/your_top_10_most_annoying_tech_products.htmlPC WorldApril 16, 2007
